rsbNotes.title: James 4:1
rsbNotes.text: 4:1 fights. James probes the root cause of divisions among the saints. They are caused by evil desires. Envy is still in view as an evil desire that is destructive.

rsbNotes.title: James 4:2
rsbNotes.text: 4:2 you do not ask. That is, “you do not ask” from “God, who gives generously to all” (1:5). Envy is a sin against God. It flows from a lack of gratitude toward God who bestows gifts upon His people. It also results from a failure to seek one’s own gifts from God rather than from the world.

rsbNotes.title: James 4:3
rsbNotes.text: 4:3 wrongly. God refuses to grant our petitions when they proceed from evil desires. To pray from wrong motives is not to pray in faith (Rom. 14:23; Heb. 11:6).

rsbNotes.title: James 4:4
rsbNotes.text: 4:4 adulterous people. Spiritual infidelity is in view here.

rsbNotes.title: James 4:5
rsbNotes.text: 4:5 Scripture says. James probably did not have one specific text in mind, a problem similar to that found in Matt. 2:23. The idea may derive partly from Ex. 20:5; Deut. 4:24. If the verse is understood as speaking of the human spirit, James is thinking of texts like Gen. 6:3; 8:21, about the consequences of original sin.

rsbNotes.title: James 4:6
rsbNotes.text: 4:6 See Prov. 3:34.

rsbNotes.title: James 4:7
rsbNotes.text:
4:7 Submit. This requires a willing act of accepting the authority of God. We are under His authority whether we submit to it or not. Here “submit” means “to obey.”

Resist the devil, and he will flee. Satan is not equal in power or authority to God. Though Satan is powerful, he is not invincible. He flees from saints wearing the armor of God who resist him.

rsbNotes.title: James 4:9
rsbNotes.text: 4:9 Be wretched and mourn and weep. This is a call to genuine repentance by which we mourn for our sins.

rsbNotes.title: James 4:11
rsbNotes.text: 4:11 speak evil. A sin of speech, slander flows out of envy and reflects the work of Satan. The Greek word for “devil” means “slanderer.” Slandering other Christians destroys fellowship and breaks the royal law. When we speak falsely against a fellow believer, we speak not only against the person but against the law of God. The slanderer sets himself above the law.

rsbNotes.title: James 4:14
rsbNotes.text: 4:14 know what tomorrow will bring. James rebukes the person who lives life and makes future plans without any regard for the providence of God. Such a person lives without regard for divine sovereignty.

rsbNotes.title: James 4:15
rsbNotes.text: 4:15 If the Lord wills. The word “if” refers to future events that are conditional. Here the primary consideration in all future planning is the will of the sovereign God.

rsbNotes.title: James 4:16
rsbNotes.text: 4:16 boast. Boasting of one’s own power and accomplishments is evil. The Christian is to boast only of the Lord (2 Cor. 11:30; 12:5, 9).

rsbNotes.title: James 4:17
rsbNotes.text: 4:17 sin. The sins of neglect and of omission are in view here.
